t: Psalm 68
God Shall Scatter His Enemies
To the choirmaster. A Psalm of David. A Song.
God*pn shall arise, his enemies shall be scattered; and*ld those who hate him shall flee before him!
As*ln smoke is driven away, so you shall drive them away; as*ld wax melts before fire, so*ld the wicked shall perish before God!
But*ln the righteous shall be glad; they*ld shall exult before God; they*ld shall be jubilant with joy!
Sing*pn to God, sing praises to his name; lift*ld up a song to him who rides through the deserts; his*ln name is the Lord;*s exult*ld before him!
Father*ln of the fatherless and protector of widows is*ld God in his holy habitation.
God*ln settles the solitary in a home; he*ld leads out the prisoners to prosperity, but*ld the rebellious dwell in a parched land.
O*pn God, when you went out before your people, when*ld you marched through the wilderness, Selah*ig
the*ln earth quaked, the heavens poured down rain, before*ld God, the One of Sinai, before*ld God, the God of Israel.
Rain*ln in abundance, O God, you shed abroad; you*ld restored your inheritance as it languished;
your*ln flock found a dwelling in it; in*ld your goodness, O God, you provided for the needy.
The*pn Lord gives the word; the*ld women who announce the news are a great host:
“The*ld kings of the armies— they flee, they flee!” The*ln women at home divide the spoil—
though*ld you men lie among the sheepfolds— the*ln wings of a dove covered with silver, its*ld pinions with shimmering gold.
When*ln the Almighty scatters kings there, let*ld snow fall on Zalmon.
O*pn mountain of God, mountain of Bashan; O*ld many-peaked mountain, mountain of Bashan!
Why*ln do you look with hatred, O many-peaked mountain, at*ld the mount that God desired for his abode, yes,*ld where the Lord*s will dwell forever?
The*ln chariots of God are twice ten thousand, thousands*ld upon thousands; the*ld Lord is among them; Sinai is now in the sanctuary.
You*ln ascended on high, leading*ld a host of captives in your train and*ld receiving gifts among men, even*ln among the rebellious, that the Lord*s God may dwell there.
Blessed*pn be the Lord, who*ld daily bears us up; God*ld is our salvation. Selah*ig
Our*ln God is a God of salvation, and*ld to God,*s the Lord, belong deliverances from death.
But*ln God will strike the heads of his enemies, the*ld hairy crown of him who walks in his guilty ways.
The*ln Lord said, “I*ld will bring them back from Bashan, I*ln will bring them back from the depths of the sea,
that*ln you may strike your feet in their blood, that*ld the tongues of your dogs may have their portion from the foe.”
Your*pn procession is seen, O God, the*ld procession of my God, my King, into the sanctuary—
the*ln singers in front, the musicians last, between*ld them virgins playing tambourines:
“Bless*ln God in the great congregation, the*ld Lord,*s O you who are of Israel’s fountain!”
There*ln is Benjamin, the least of them, in the lead, the*ld princes of Judah in their throng, the*ld princes of Zebulun, the princes of Naphtali.
Summon*pn your power, O God, the*ld power, O God, by which you have worked for us.
Because*ln of your temple at Jerusalem kings*ld shall bear gifts to you.
Rebuke*ln the beasts that dwell among the reeds, the*ld herd of bulls with the calves of the peoples. Trample*ln underfoot those who lust after tribute; scatter*ld the peoples who delight in war.
Nobles*ln shall come from Egypt; Cush*ld shall hasten to stretch out her hands to God.
O*pn kingdoms of the earth, sing to God; sing*ld praises to the Lord, Selah*ig
to*ln him who rides in the heavens, the ancient heavens; behold,*ld he sends out his voice, his mighty voice.
Ascribe*ln power to God, whose*ld majesty is over Israel, and*ld whose power is in the skies.
Awesome*ln is God from his sanctuary; the*ld God of Israel— he is the one who gives power and strength to his people. Blessed*ln be God!
